_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Batesville Compressor Station ("Batesville" or "Facility"), located near the town of Senecaville Ohio utilizes more than the threshold quantity of a "regulated flammable substance" (10,000 pounds) in the processing of natural gas. Therefore, this Facility is subject to the Risk

Management Plan (RMP) requirements codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68) administered by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA).  Batesville is also subject to Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA's) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119);. Upon completion of modeling, Smith & Burgess found there were off-site receptors identified using EPA MARPLOT that could be impacted by the RMP scenarios. Therefore, Batesville is subject to Program 3 requirements as stated in 40 CFR 68.10. OSHA's PSM standard closely parallels requirements outlined in US EPA's RMP Rule. All elements required by US EPA's 40 CFR 68 - Program 3 Prevention Program are also required by OSHA's PSM.



a) The accidental release prevention and emergency response policies at the stationary source

Batesville employs one (1) full-time employee on-site who will ensure the proper operation and maintenance of the Facility.  Batesville maintains a policy of safe condensate handling operations, reducing to the greatest extent possible hazards associated with the extraction processes, and reducing subsequent risk to the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.  Batesville has procedures in place, including both on-site activities and coordination with off-site responders that are to be followed in the event of a flammable material release. This Facility is submitting its first RMP to the US EPA. The Facility is non responsive.



b) The stationary source and regulated substances handled

Based on worst-case analysis, the distance to the endpoint does not encompass any public receptors. Upon completion of modeling, Smith & Bur

gess found that EPA MARPLOT identified offsite receptors. EPA MARPLOT identifies 2 housing units with a population of 11 within the WCS radius based on 2010 Census data. Therefore, Batesville is classified as a Program 3 Facility. The processes at the plant are interconnected by piping and fit the EPA's definition of a stationary source in 40 CFR part 68.  The plant boundaries of the stationary source begin at the pig receiver at the plant inlet and end at the pig launcher plant discharge just after the 10" block valve tied to ESD-3000. This plant is designed to receive natural gas from a pipeline. The gas process begins with inlet separation to remove any pipeline liquids. These "Y-Grade" liquids are stabilized as a condensate to remove any materials that are not atmospheric stable liquids, sent to storage and can then be trucked off

site. The remaining gas is then compressed to pipeline pressures and goes through a dehydration process to ensure most of the water is removed from the gas before being exported offsite.  The Batesville Compressor Station was evaluated to determine if any regulated flammable or

toxic substances exceeded a defined threshold quantity. The listed flammable substances that are stored above threshold quantities at Batesville are natural gas, unstabilized condensate, stabilized condensate, and natural gas liquids. The flammable components of these substances include methane, ethane, propane, butanes, pentanes, hexanes, and heavier alkanes. This Facility is subject to the Risk Management Plan (RMP) requirements codified in Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68) administered by the US EPA.



c) The general accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps

Batesville employs one (1) full-time employee on-site who will ensure the proper operation and maintenance of the Facility. This Facility is submitting its first RMP to the US EPA.  Batesville maintains a consistent accidental release pr

evention program to eliminate or minimize

releases of NGL, condensate, and other RMP-regulated flammables. As previously indicated, the Prevention Program required under 40 CFR 68 is identical to the Prevention Program required under OSHA's PSM.  Batesville Prevention Program 3 elements, as required under 40 CFR 68 Subpart D, are included in the Facility's PSM Plan, which is kept at the Marietta Ohio office. Required elements include:

Employee Participation,

Process Safety Information,

Process Hazard Analysis,

Operating Procedures,

Training,

Contractors,

Pre-startup Review,

Mechanical Integrity,

Hot Work Permits,

Management of Change,

Incident Investigation, and

Compliance Audits.



d) The five-year accident history

The Batesville Compressor Station has not had an accidental release of a regulated substance where exposure to the substance, its reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any off-site death, injury, or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor within the last five (5) years.



e) The emergency response program

The Emergency Response Program requirements for Program 3 Facilities are very similar to those required under the PSM rule. The Emergency Response Program required under the RMP and PSM Rules must be site-specific and comprehensive, including the following elements:

-Public and emergency response agency notification procedures;

-Proper first aid and emergency medical treatment;

-Emergency response measures;

-Procedures for inspecting, testing, and maintaining emergency response equipment;

-Employee training; and

-Program review procedures.



EnLink maintains a corporate Emergency Preparedness and Response Plan (EPRP) that provides guidance for emergencies expected at all EnLink facilities, including Batesville, as well as additional safety information. Batesville also maintains a

site-specific Emergency Action Plan.  In addition, operating procedures and equipment design codes and standards associated with the operations at the Facility are maintained. Furthermore, the Facility has coordinated the emergency response with the local fire department. For these reasons, Batesville meets the exceptions listed in 40 CFR 68.90(b), and therefore the Facility is not required to have the Emergency Response Program as described in 40 CFR 68.95. As such, the Facility is non responsive.



f) Planned changes to improve safety

The Facility last completed a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) during design of the Facility in 2016 to assess potential areas to improve safety at the Facility. The final action item from the PHA was completed before startup. Pre-startup safety reviews (PSSRs) are conducted on a

regular basis whenever changes are made to the process. The Facility will update and revalidate the PHA every 5 years as per OSHA PSM and EPA RMP regulations.
